name: Vitiligo
description: Vitiligo is a long-term skin condition in which white patches appear on the skin due to loss of pigment (melanin). It happens when pigment-producing cells (melanocytes) stop working or die. It is not contagious and can affect any age group.

stages.Early: Small white or light-colored patches start appearing on the skin, commonly on hands, face, feet, or around the eyes and mouth.
stages.Progressive: The white patches increase in size and number and may spread to other parts of the body. Hair in the affected area may turn white.
stages.Advanced: Large areas of skin lose color and patches become more noticeable and widespread.

causes: Vitiligo is mainly an autoimmune condition where the body's immune system attacks the pigment-producing cells. The exact cause is not fully known, but genetics, stress, and other immune disorders may increase the risk.
risk_factors: Family history of vitiligo or autoimmune diseases, stress, skin injury, and other immune system disorders.
preventive_measures: There is no sure way to prevent vitiligo, but protecting the skin from sunburn, avoiding skin injuries, managing stress, and using sunscreen can help reduce damage.
solution: Treatment focuses on restoring skin color and stopping the spread. This includes topical creams, light therapy (phototherapy), skin grafting in severe cases, and cosmetic camouflage. A doctor should guide treatment.
